==German== {{wikipedia|lang=de}} ===Alternative forms=== {{lb|de|obsolete spellings}} * {{l|de|Caffe}}, {{l|de|Kaffe}} * {{l|de|Caffee}} * {{l|de|Caffeh}}, {{l|de|Kaffeh}} * {{l|de|Coffe}}, {{l|de|Koffe}} * {{l|de|Coffee}}, {{l|de|Koffee}} * {{l|de|Coffeh}}, {{l|de|Koffeh}} ===Etymology=== Borrowed from {{bor|de|fr|café}} in the seventeenth century, while the o-Variants – which fell into disuse with the nineteenth century – are from {{bor|de|en|coffee}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈkafe/}} {{a|overall the most common variant}} * {{IPA|de|/kaˈfeː/}} {{a|Austrian; occasionally elsewhere, but widely perceived as snobbish}} * {{IPA|de|/ˈkafə/}} {{a|parts of northern and eastern Germany}} * {{audio|de|De-Kaffee.ogg}} {{IPA|de|[kʰaˈfeː‿ˈkʰafe]}} * {{a|Austria}} {{audio|de|De-at-Kaffee.ogg}} * {{hyphenation|de|Kaf|fee}} * {{rhymes|de|afe|afə|eː}} * {{homophones|de|Café}} {{qualifier|only according to the Austrian pronunciation of ''Kaffee''}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|m|Kaffees|Kaffees|Käffchen|dim2=Käfflein}} # [[coffee]] {{gloss|beverage made by infusing the beans of the coffee plant in hot water}} # {{lb|de|regional}} [[afternoon]] coffee, [[coffee]] and [[cake]] {{gloss|afternoon meal in northern and central Germany, particularly on Sundays}} #: ''Wir fahren am Sonntag zum '''Kaffee''' zur Oma.'' #:: On Sunday, we go to Grandma's for '''coffee [and cake]'''. ====Usage notes==== * {{sense|beverage}} As with most beverages in German, the plural ''Kaffees'' is only used to mean “several ''kinds'' of coffee”. Otherwise the singular form is used: ''Zwei '''Kaffee''', bitte!'' – “Two '''coffees''', please!” * {{sense|meal}} The use for the afternoon meal is still applicable if one prefers other beverages, such as tea. It would not be all too extraordinary to say: ''Wir trinken meistens Tee zum '''Kaffee'''.'' — {{q|literally}} We usually have tea for '''coffee'''. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-m|s|s}}
